clusters.title: US Senate passes bill to end longest ever government shutdown

items.title: US Senate passes bill to end longest ever government shutdown
items.standfirst: US Senate approves a spending package to fund the government through January following a weekend of negotiations.
items.content: US Senate approves a spending package to fund the government through January following a weekend of negotiations.

items.title: US Senate approves bill to end shutdown, sending it to the House
US Senate passes bill to end record government shutdown after bipartisan deal
items.standfirst: The longest US government shutdown moved closer to ending on Monday after several Democrats joined Republicans in a 60-40 vote for a compromise funding deal, drawing party backlash. The shutdown, now in its 40th day, has left over a million workers unpaid and caused major air travel disruptions.
items.content: The longest US government shutdown moved closer to ending on Monday after several Democrats joined Republicans in a 60-40 vote for a compromise funding deal, drawing party backlash. The shutdown, now in its 40th day, has left over a million workers unpaid and caused major air travel disruptions.

items.title: Senate approves package that would end the longest government shutdown in US history – as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Senate passes funding package to end shutdown after Democrats break ranksThe eight Democratic and Independent senators who broke ranks with the party to advance a bill that would end the government shutdown – the longest in US history – have defended their decisions amid furor from their party and base.“What happened tonight is not the closing of a chapter. It’s the opening of an opportunity. What the chapter does close is the damaging shutdown that is only getting worse, that is only going to impact more and more people,” said Angus King, the Independent lawmaker from Maine who caucuses with Democrats. Continue reading...
items.content: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Senate passes funding package to end shutdown after Democrats break ranksThe eight Democratic and Independent senators who broke ranks with the party to advance a bill that would end the government shutdown – the longest in US history – have defended their decisions amid furor from their party and base.“What happened tonight is not the closing of a chapter. It’s the opening of an opportunity. What the chapter does close is the damaging shutdown that is only getting worse, that is only going to impact more and more people,” said Angus King, the Independent lawmaker from Maine who caucuses with Democrats. Continue reading...

items.content: After 41 days of a government shutdown, the U.S. Senate has passed a set of bills to reopen the government. Its fate in the House is uncertain.(Image credit: Tom Brenner)

items.title: Senate approves funding deal to end longest US government shutdown
items.standfirst: Bill, which passed 60-40 but does not include key health concession demanded by Democrats, now heads to HouseThe Senate on Monday approved a funding package that is expected to bring to a close the longest government shutdown in US history, after a coalition of Democrats broke from their party and voted with Republicans, in a move that has enraged many in their caucus.The vote passed in a 60-40 tally, with seven Democrats and one independent joining all Republicans to approve a compromise deal that would fund most federal agencies through January. The agreement, which next goes to the House of Representatives, does not directly address the expiring tax credits for healthcare premiums, the issue at the center of the 40-day stalemate between Democrats and Republicans, though the Senate majority leader John Thune has promised a Senate vote later this year on the subsidies. Continue reading...
items.content: Bill, which passed 60-40 but does not include key health concession demanded by Democrats, now heads to HouseThe Senate on Monday approved a funding package that is expected to bring to a close the longest government shutdown in US history, after a coalition of Democrats broke from their party and voted with Republicans, in a move that has enraged many in their caucus.The vote passed in a 60-40 tally, with seven Democrats and one independent joining all Republicans to approve a compromise deal that would fund most federal agencies through January. The agreement, which next goes to the House of Representatives, does not directly address the expiring tax credits for healthcare premiums, the issue at the center of the 40-day stalemate between Democrats and Republicans, though the Senate majority leader John Thune has promised a Senate vote later this year on the subsidies. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The US Senate approved a spending package to fund the government through January after negotiations.
The Senate voted 60-40 to pass a compromise funding deal, ending the 40-day shutdown.
The shutdown left over a million workers unpaid and caused major air travel disruptions.
Several Democrats joined Republicans to pass the bill, drawing party backlash.
The bill now goes to the House of Representatives for further consideration.

items.title: Syria to join US-led coalition to defeat IS group after Trump meeting
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Sharaa, once branded a terrorist by the US, became the first Syrian leader to visit the White House.
items.content: Ahmed al-Sharaa, once branded a terrorist by the US, became the first Syrian leader to visit the White House.

items.title: US declares partial suspension of sanctions on Syria after historic meeting
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Sharaa and Donald Trump hold first White House summit between a US and Syrian leader since 1946The US has announced a partial suspension of sanctions on Syria after a historic meeting in Washington DC between its new leader, Ahmed al-Sharaa, and Donald Trump.Monday’s meeting was the first summit between a US and Syrian leader at the White House since 1946. The meeting is part of a remarkable turnaround in US-Syrian relations after the fall of Bashar al-Assad, who had prosecuted a deadly civil war in the country from 2011 until his forces collapsed in December 2024. Continue reading...
items.content: Ahmed al-Sharaa and Donald Trump hold first White House summit between a US and Syrian leader since 1946The US has announced a partial suspension of sanctions on Syria after a historic meeting in Washington DC between its new leader, Ahmed al-Sharaa, and Donald Trump.Monday’s meeting was the first summit between a US and Syrian leader at the White House since 1946. The meeting is part of a remarkable turnaround in US-Syrian relations after the fall of Bashar al-Assad, who had prosecuted a deadly civil war in the country from 2011 until his forces collapsed in December 2024. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump hosts Syria’s Sharaa at White House; Damascus joins anti-IS group coalition
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump hosted his Syrian counterpart President Ahmed al-Sharaa for unprecedented talks at the White House on Monday. Although the meeting was held behind closed doors and few policy details were provided afterward, Washington welcomed the once-pariah state into its international coalition to fight the Islamic State (IS) group.
items.content: US President Donald Trump hosted his Syrian counterpart President Ahmed al-Sharaa for unprecedented talks at the White House on Monday. Although the meeting was held behind closed doors and few policy details were provided afterward, Washington welcomed the once-pariah state into its international coalition to fight the Islamic State (IS) group.

items.title: Syria's grand pivot : What next after Al-Sharaa's historic White House visit ?

items.content: From radical insurgent with a 10-million dollar bounty on his head to a red carpet welcome at the White House, the rebranding of Ahmed Al Sharaa’s now complete.

items.content: Syrian presidency says al-Sharaa and Trump discussed ways to 'strengthen and develop' ties between the US and Syria.

items.title: Syria seeks alliances with Turkey, Gulf states, West, and envisions a 'new partnership' with Russia
items.standfirst: Syria's President Ahmed al-Sharaa met US President Donald Trump at the White House on Monday for unprecedented talks, just days after Washington removed him from a terrorism blacklist. Sharaa, whose rebel forces ousted longtime ruler Bashar al-Assad late last year, is the first Syrian leader to visit the White House since the country's 1946 independence. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Yinka Oyetade welcomes Dr. Jerome Drevon, Author, Senior Analyst in Jihad and Modern Conflict at the International Crisis Group (ICG).
items.content: Syria's President Ahmed al-Sharaa met US President Donald Trump at the White House on Monday for unprecedented talks, just days after Washington removed him from a terrorism blacklist. Sharaa, whose rebel forces ousted longtime ruler Bashar al-Assad late last year, is the first Syrian leader to visit the White House since the country's 1946 independence. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Yinka Oyetade welcomes Dr. Jerome Drevon, Author, Senior Analyst in Jihad and Modern Conflict at the International Crisis Group (ICG).

items.content: Former al Qaeda commander and now Syrian leader Ahmed al Sharaa has been welcomed by Donald Trump to the White House.

items.title: Syria’s al-Sharaa greets supporters after historic visit to White House

items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa greeted flag-waving supporters outside of the White House.

items.title: Trump to meet Sharaa at White House, capping major turnaround for Syria
items.standfirst: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa's White House meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday caps a stunning year for the rebel-turned-ruler who toppled a longtime autocratic leader and has since toured the world as he seeks to end Syria's international isolation.
items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa's White House meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday caps a stunning year for the rebel-turned-ruler who toppled a longtime autocratic leader and has since toured the world as he seeks to end Syria's international isolation.

items.title: Trump 'aims to bring Syria into Abraham Accords' with Sharaa’s historic White House visit
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Sharaa becomes the first Syrian president to visit the White House on Monday, capping an extraordinary turnaround for the former al Qaeda operative who is now leading efforts to end his country’s international isolation. Sharaa will push for the permanent lifting of sanctions on Syria when he meets with US President Donald Trump, who hopes in return to bring Damascus into the Abraham Accords normalising ties between Israel and several Arab states.
items.content: Ahmed al-Sharaa becomes the first Syrian president to visit the White House on Monday, capping an extraordinary turnaround for the former al Qaeda operative who is now leading efforts to end his country’s international isolation. Sharaa will push for the permanent lifting of sanctions on Syria when he meets with US President Donald Trump, who hopes in return to bring Damascus into the Abraham Accords normalising ties between Israel and several Arab states.

items.title: From jailed jihadist to the Oval Office: Syria's president caps unlikely rise with Trump meeting
items.standfirst: Syrian interim President Ahmed al-Sharaa will meet with President Donald Trump in Washington on Monday.
items.content: Syrian interim President Ahmed al-Sharaa will meet with President Donald Trump in Washington on Monday.

items.title: Syrian president holds talks with Trump at White House
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Sharaa was expected to push for full lifting of remaining sanctions imposed during 13-year civil warSyria’s president, Ahmed al-Sharaa, has held talks with Donald Trump at the White House, the first such official visit by a Syrian leader since national independence in 1946. He was expected to push for a full lifting of the remaining sanctions on his war-ravaged country.Sharaa, whose Islamist rebel forces toppled the longtime ruler Bashar al-Assad late last year, has courted the US president to try to reverse the economic restrictions imposed during the 13-year civil war, arguing they are no longer justified. Continue reading...
items.content: Ahmed al-Sharaa was expected to push for full lifting of remaining sanctions imposed during 13-year civil warSyria’s president, Ahmed al-Sharaa, has held talks with Donald Trump at the White House, the first such official visit by a Syrian leader since national independence in 1946. He was expected to push for a full lifting of the remaining sanctions on his war-ravaged country.Sharaa, whose Islamist rebel forces toppled the longtime ruler Bashar al-Assad late last year, has courted the US president to try to reverse the economic restrictions imposed during the 13-year civil war, arguing they are no longer justified. Continue reading...

items.title: From US enemy to ally? Why ex-jihadist Syrian president's meeting with Trump is a big deal
items.standfirst: It is a moment few could have imagined just a few years ago but the Syrian president, Ahmed al Sharaa, has arrived in Washington for a landmark series of meetings, which will culminate in a face-to-face with Donald Trump at the White House.
items.content: It is a moment few could have imagined just a few years ago but the Syrian president, Ahmed al Sharaa, has arrived in Washington for a landmark series of meetings, which will culminate in a face-to-face with Donald Trump at the White House.

items.title: Syria's Sharaa arrives in US for Trump talks after sanctions lifted
items.standfirst: The Syrian leader will meet the US President at the White House on Monday for security talks.
items.content: The Syrian leader will meet the US President at the White House on Monday for security talks.

ai_summary: Ahmed al-Sharaa, the Syrian leader, met with Donald Trump at the White House.
This meeting was the first summit between US and Syrian leaders since 1946.
The US announced a partial suspension of sanctions on Syria after the meeting.
Washington welcomed Syria into its coalition to fight the Islamic State group.
Al-Sharaa was once branded a terrorist by the US, now welcomed in Washington.

items.title: Several killed in car blast near New Delhi’s Red Fort
items.standfirst: At least eight people were killed and 19 others injured when a car exploded near New Delhi’s historic Red Fort on Monday, police said. The cause of the blast is still being investigated. According to local media, a former owner of the car has been arrested.
items.content: At least eight people were killed and 19 others injured when a car exploded near New Delhi’s historic Red Fort on Monday, police said. The cause of the blast is still being investigated. According to local media, a former owner of the car has been arrested.

items.title: At least eight killed after car explodes near Delhi's Red Fort

items.content: Twenty more were injured in the blast, the cause of which is still unknown, authorities say.

items.title: Car explosion near Red Fort in India's capital kills at least 8 people, police say
items.standfirst: A car exploded near the 17th century Red Fort in New Delhi on Monday, killing at least eight people, injuring others and triggering a fire that damaged vehicles parked nearby, New Delhi police said.
items.content: A car exploded near the 17th century Red Fort in New Delhi on Monday, killing at least eight people, injuring others and triggering a fire that damaged vehicles parked nearby, New Delhi police said.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: Eight people die and several injured after car explosion in Delhi, police say
items.standfirst: Several fire engines rushed to the scene after blast reported near the historic Red Fort, fire services saidA car explosion outside the historic Red Fort monument in Delhi has killed at least eight people and started a fire in the surrounding area, according to police.The cause of the explosion, which took place just before 7pm local time (1330 GMT) on Monday night, is being investigated. The registered owner of the car has reportedly been detained for questioning. Continue reading...
items.content: Several fire engines rushed to the scene after blast reported near the historic Red Fort, fire services saidA car explosion outside the historic Red Fort monument in Delhi has killed at least eight people and started a fire in the surrounding area, according to police.The cause of the explosion, which took place just before 7pm local time (1330 GMT) on Monday night, is being investigated. The registered owner of the car has reportedly been detained for questioning. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: At least eight people have been killed and 19 others were injured after a car exploded in the Indian capital New Delhi, say police.
items.content: At least eight people have been killed and 19 others were injured after a car exploded in the Indian capital New Delhi, say police.

ai_summary: An explosion near the Red Fort in New Delhi killed at least eight people.
Nineteen others were injured in the car explosion on Monday.
The cause of the blast is still under investigation by authorities.
A former owner of the car has been arrested by police.
Several fire engines rushed to the scene after the explosion.

clusters.title: Trump threatens to sue BBC for $1 billion over January 6 speech edit
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Threatens Legal Action Against BBC Over Editing Of His Jan 6 Speech

items.title: Trump threatens to sue BBC for $1 billion over January 6 speech edit
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion, alleging that the British public broadcaster attempted to “interfere in the presidential election” last year by editing his January 6th speech. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez has the details, as two top executives have already resigned amid mounting pressure on the organization.
items.content: President Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion, alleging that the British public broadcaster attempted to “interfere in the presidential election” last year by editing his January 6th speech. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez has the details, as two top executives have already resigned amid mounting pressure on the organization.

items.title: Why have BBC bosses Tim Davie and Deborah Turness resigned?

items.content: The BBC has come under fire over a Panorama documentary that was accused of misleadingly editing a speech by Donald Trump.

items.title: BBC News CEO Deborah Turness resigns over Trump speech edit
items.standfirst: The head of the BBC and the British broadcaster’s top news executive both resigned after criticism of the way the organization edited a speech by President Donald Trump. The BBC said Director-General Tim Davie and news CEO Deborah Turness had both decided to leave the corporation.
items.content: The head of the BBC and the British broadcaster’s top news executive both resigned after criticism of the way the organization edited a speech by President Donald Trump. The BBC said Director-General Tim Davie and news CEO Deborah Turness had both decided to leave the corporation.

items.title: Why have BBC bosses resigned over a Trump speech edit?
items.standfirst: Following accusations of bias at the BBC, Tim Davie says departure is 'my own decision', while head of news also quits.
items.content: Following accusations of bias at the BBC, Tim Davie says departure is 'my own decision', while head of news also quits.

items.title: BBC chair's letter to the Culture, Media and Sport Committee in full
items.standfirst: Samir Shah has apologised for an "error of judgement" over the editing of a speech by Donald Trump in a BBC Panorama documentary.
items.content: Samir Shah has apologised for an "error of judgement" over the editing of a speech by Donald Trump in a BBC Panorama documentary.

ai_summary: Donald Trump threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion over speech editing.
Trump alleges the BBC attempted to interfere in the presidential election.
The BBC's director general and head of news resigned after criticism.
The criticism focused on a Panorama documentary's editing of Trump's speech.
The BBC chair apologized for an "error of judgement" in the editing.

clusters.title: Nicolas Sarkozy says he wants to ‘prove his innocence’ as he is released from prison
clusters.neutral_headline: Sarkozy Released from Prison Pending Appeal

items.title: Nicolas Sarkozy says he wants to ‘prove his innocence’ as he is released from prison
items.standfirst: Former French president, who said his three weeks in jail had been a ‘nightmare’, will serve rest of sentence outside pending appealNicolas Sarkozy has said he wants to “prove his innocence” after being released from prison while he appeals against his conviction for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to obtain election campaign funds from Libya.After 20 days in jail that he had earlier described as “gruelling” and a “nightmare”, the former French president was driven away from La Santé prison in Paris on Monday accompanied by his wife, the singer Carla Bruni-Sarkozy. Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president, who said his three weeks in jail had been a ‘nightmare’, will serve rest of sentence outside pending appealNicolas Sarkozy has said he wants to “prove his innocence” after being released from prison while he appeals against his conviction for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to obtain election campaign funds from Libya.After 20 days in jail that he had earlier described as “gruelling” and a “nightmare”, the former French president was driven away from La Santé prison in Paris on Monday accompanied by his wife, the singer Carla Bruni-Sarkozy. Continue reading...

items.title: Release of Sarkozy, pending appeal, 'isn't end of sentence: It's morphing into something else'
items.standfirst: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy will be released from prison and placed under judicial supervision, a Paris appeals court has ruled, less than three weeks after he began serving a five-year sentence over a scheme to finance his 2007 election campaign with funds from Libya. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Annette Young welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.
items.content: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy will be released from prison and placed under judicial supervision, a Paris appeals court has ruled, less than three weeks after he began serving a five-year sentence over a scheme to finance his 2007 election campaign with funds from Libya. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Annette Young welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.

items.title: Former French president Sarkozy released from prison after three weeks
items.standfirst: The former French president was jailed in October for conspiring to fund his election campaign with money from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.
items.content: The former French president was jailed in October for conspiring to fund his election campaign with money from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.

items.title: Sarkozy freed from prison and put under ‘judicial supervision’ pending appeal – as it happened
items.standfirst: Former French president, who is appealing against a conviction for criminal conspiracy, is released from prison in Paris. This live blog is closedAs we are waiting for the Paris court decision on Sarkozy to come, expected around 13.30 local time (12.30 GMT), let’s take a look at other news across Europe.If Sarkozy gets released with an ankle tag, it won’t be his first: Reuters notes that last year, France’s highest court upheld a separate conviction for corruption and influence peddling, ordering him to wear an electronic tag for a year, a first for a former French head of state. The tag has now been removed. Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president, who is appealing against a conviction for criminal conspiracy, is released from prison in Paris. This live blog is closedAs we are waiting for the Paris court decision on Sarkozy to come, expected around 13.30 local time (12.30 GMT), let’s take a look at other news across Europe.If Sarkozy gets released with an ankle tag, it won’t be his first: Reuters notes that last year, France’s highest court upheld a separate conviction for corruption and influence peddling, ordering him to wear an electronic tag for a year, a first for a former French head of state. items.content: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been freed from jail after just 20 days in jail pending his appeal against his conviction for conspiring to raise funds from Libya.

clusters.title: Canada no longer measles-free as outbreaks spread

items.title: Canada no longer measles-free as outbreaks spread
items.standfirst: Canada has lost its measles elimination status as vaccination rates have slipped below the 95% coverage rate needed to stop outbreaksCanada is no longer measles-free because of ongoing outbreaks, international health experts said on Monday, as childhood vaccination rates fall and the highly contagious virus spreads across North and South America.The loss of the country’s measles elimination status comes more than a year after the highly contagious virus started spreading. Continue reading...
items.content: Canada has lost its measles elimination status as vaccination rates have slipped below the 95% coverage rate needed to stop outbreaksCanada is no longer measles-free because of ongoing outbreaks, international health experts said on Monday, as childhood vaccination rates fall and the highly contagious virus spreads across North and South America.The loss of the country’s measles elimination status comes more than a year after the highly contagious virus started spreading. items.title: Canada loses measles elimination status after deadly resurgence linked to religious group
items.standfirst: Canada has lost its measles elimination status after almost three decades, health officials said on Monday, citing a persistent resurgence of the virus largely among unvaccinated groups. Canada’s latest outbreak has lasted for more than a year.

items.title: Trump asks supreme court to throw out jury’s finding in E Jean Carroll lawsuit
items.standfirst: Writer and author had testified, and won, at trial that the president had sexually assaulted her in the mid-1990sDonald Trump asked the US supreme court on Monday to throw out a jury’s finding in a civil lawsuit that he sexually abused writer E Jean Carroll at a Manhattan department store in the mid-1990s and later defamed her.Trump’s lawyers argued in a lengthy filing with the high court that allegations leading to the $5m verdict were “propped up” by a “series of indefensible evidentiary rulings” that allowed Carroll’s lawyers to present “highly inflammatory propensity evidence” against him. Continue reading...

items.title: Doctor unpacks FDA's removal of "black box" warnings on some menopause hormone therapies
items.standfirst: The FDA says it will remove the "black box" warning labels on many hormone therapy drugs used to treat menopause and perimenopause. Dr. Tami Rowen, an associate professor at the University of California, San Francisco, joins to break down the announcement.
items.content: The FDA says it will remove the "black box" warning labels on many hormone therapy drugs used to treat menopause and perimenopause. Dr. Tami Rowen, an associate professor at the University of California, San Francisco, joins to break down the announcement.

items.title: Why warning labels on some menopause hormone therapies are being removed
items.standfirst: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration will remove the "black box" warning labels on many hormone therapy drugs used for menopause and perimenopause symptoms -- a major turnaround that's likely to encourage more women to seek treatment. FDA Commissioner Dr. Marty Makary spoke exclusively to senior correspondent Norah O'Donnell.
items.content: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration will remove the "black box" warning labels on many hormone therapy drugs used for menopause and perimenopause symptoms -- a major turnaround that's likely to encourage more women to seek treatment. FDA Commissioner Dr. Marty Makary spoke exclusively to senior correspondent Norah O'Donnell.

items.title: FDA to remove "black box" warnings on some menopause hormone therapies
items.standfirst: The Food and Drug Administration says it is removing safety warnings for many hormone therapy drugs prescribed to ease symptoms of menopause and perimenopause. Dr. Erika Schwartz, founder of the Evolved Science medical group in New York City, joins with her reaction.
items.content: The Food and Drug Administration says it is removing safety warnings for many hormone therapy drugs prescribed to ease symptoms of menopause and perimenopause. Dr. Erika Schwartz, founder of the Evolved Science medical group in New York City, joins with her reaction.

ai_summary: The FDA will remove "black box" warnings on hormone therapy drugs.

The change is likely to encourage more women to seek treatment.

items.standfirst: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla is accused of inciting terrorism and public violence after her father was jailed in 2021Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, a politician and daughter of the former South African president Jacob Zuma, has pleaded not guilty to incitement to commit terrorism and public violence over deadly riots in 2021.The trial, which began on Monday in the coastal city of Durban, is the first prosecution in South Africa in which terrorism‑related charges are being brought based on social media posts. clusters.title: Weather tracker: Typhoon Fung-Wong becomes second in a week to hit the Philippines
clusters.neutral_headline: Typhoon Fung-Wong Hits Philippines, Evacuations Occur

items.title: Weather tracker: Typhoon Fung-Wong becomes second in a week to hit the Philippines
items.standfirst: Destructive winds and rainfall hit archipelago, while a cold spell in Florida prompts fears of falling iguanasTyphoon Fung-Wong, locally known as Uwan, is the second in a week to affect the Philippines after making landfall on Sunday evening. The weather system prompted warnings for heavy rainfall and life-threatening storm surges across much of the country, with sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of about 140mph recorded on Sunday by the national meteorological agency.By the time Fung-Wong moves past the Philippines early this week, more than 200mm of rainfall is expected to have fallen on Luzon, the country’s most populous island. Continue reading...
items.content: Destructive winds and rainfall hit archipelago, while a cold spell in Florida prompts fears of falling iguanasTyphoon Fung-Wong, locally known as Uwan, is the second in a week to affect the Philippines after making landfall on Sunday evening. The weather system prompted warnings for heavy rainfall and life-threatening storm surges across much of the country, with sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of about 140mph recorded on Sunday by the national meteorological agency.By the time Fung-Wong moves past the Philippines early this week, more than 200mm of rainfall is expected to have fallen on Luzon, the country’s most populous island. Continue reading...

items.title: More than 1 million evacuated in the Philippines as Typhoon Fung-wong makes landfall
items.standfirst: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon hits Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224More than 1 million people have been evacuated from their homes in the Philippines and at least two people have been killed as Typhoon Fung-wong – the second big storm to hit in days – made landfall on the east coast.The super-typhoon crossed over the north of the archipelago’s most populous island, Luzon, with torrential rain, sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of up to 140mph (225km/h). Continue reading...
items.content: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon hits Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224More than 1 million people have been evacuated from their homes in the Philippines and at least two people have been killed as Typhoon Fung-wong – the second big storm to hit in days – made landfall on the east coast.The super-typhoon crossed over the north of the archipelago’s most populous island, Luzon, with torrential rain, sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of up to 140mph (225km/h). Continue reading...

items.title: Watch: BBC on Luzon Island as super typhoon hits Philippines

items.content: Typhoon Fung-wong has made landfall in the Philippines, where more than 900,000 people have been evacuated.

ai_summary: Typhoon Fung-wong made landfall in the Philippines, causing evacuations.
Over one million people were evacuated from their homes.
The typhoon is the second major storm to hit the country recently.
Sustained winds reached 115 mph, with gusts up to 140 mph.
At least two deaths have been reported due to the typhoon.
